title.value: The neuroanatomical substrates of autism and ADHD and their link to putative genomic underpinnings
title.justification: This is the title of the research paper.
title.quote: The neuroanatomical substrates of autism and ADHD and their link to putative genomic underpinnings

extractions.description: This paper investigates the neuroanatomical differences in autistic individuals with and without co-occurring ADHD and links these differences to potential genomic underpinnings. It uses a sample from the Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP) and explores cortical thickness (CT) and surface area (SA) differences as well as their genomic associations using data from the Allen Human Brain Atlas.

type.justification: The paper reports on an empirical investigation involving the analysis of neuroanatomical data and gene expression patterns in autistic individuals with and without ADHD.
type.quote: This study aimed to (1) investigate between-group differences in autistic individuals with and without co-occurring ADHD, and to (2) link these variances to putative genomic underpinnings.

name.justification: The paper focuses on understanding neuroanatomical and genomic differences in neurodevelopmental disorders, specifically autism and ADHD.
name.quote: To parse heterogeneity, it is essential to establish how the neurobiology of ASD is modulated by differences associated with co-occurring conditions, such as attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

name.justification: The paper directly investigates neuroanatomical differences in cortical thickness and surface area among individuals with autism and ADHD.
name.quote: We examined differences in cortical thickness (CT) and surface area (SA) and their genomic associations in a sample of 533 individuals from the Longitudinal European Autism Project.

name.justification: The paper links neuroanatomical findings to genomic data using the Allen Human Brain Atlas.
name.quote: Moreover, leveraging the spatial gene expression data of the Allen Human Brain Atlas, we identified genes whose spatial expression patterns resemble our neuroimaging findings.

name.justification: The dataset used in this study is from the Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP).
name.quote: This study utilized data provided by the EU-AIMS LEAP project, which is a European multicenter study on stratification biomarkers for autism.

referenced_paper_title.value: The EU-AIMS Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP): clinical characterization
referenced_paper_title.justification: This referenced paper is related to the EU-AIMS LEAP project whose data was utilized in the study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: This study utilized data provided by the EU-AIMS LEAP project [23], which is a European multicenter study on stratification biomarkers for autism.

name.justification: The dataset used for genomic association is the Allen Human Brain Atlas (AHBA).
name.quote: Moreover, leveraging the spatial gene expression data of the Allen Human Brain Atlas (AHBA; [27]) we aimed at linking these neuroanatomical differences to putative molecular underpinnings.

referenced_paper_title.value: An anatomically comprehensive atlas of the adult human brain transcriptome
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper provides details about the Allen Human Brain Atlas, which was used in the study for gene expression data.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Moreover, leveraging the spatial gene expression data of the Allen Human Brain Atlas (AHBA; [27]) we aimed at linking these neuroanatomical differences to putative molecular underpinnings.
